channel.title: Jamel M. Thomas
channel.description: Recent content on Jamel M. Thomas

item.title: blog
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: Plotly for College Analysis
item.description: Plotly for College Analysis In this post, we explore open college data. This dataset includes the name of the college, the aggregated number of people who passed a particular subject by transfer level and race. Letâ€™s read out data and take a look: There is a wonderful package called DT that creates interactive plots in HTML. It even comes with a search feature.

item.title: Python in R Markdown?
item.description: Python in R Markdown R Markdown supports Python integration with the package reticulate; it is fairly easy to get started. Just install the package and run! Here is a list of all supported languages. names(knitr::knit_engines$get()) ## [1] "awk" "bash" "coffee" "gawk" "groovy" ## [6] "haskell" "lein" "mysql" "node" "octave" ## [11] "perl" "psql" "Rscript" "ruby" "sas" ## [16] "scala" "sed" "sh" "stata" "zsh" ## [21] "highlight" "Rcpp" "tikz" "dot" "c" ## [26] "fortran" "fortran95" "asy" "cat" "asis" ## [31] "stan" "block" "block2" "js" "css" ## [36] "sql" "go" "python" "julia" "theorem" ## [41] "lemma" "definition" "corollary" "proposition" "example" ## [46] "exercise" "proof" "remark" "solution" install.

item.title: Where have I been?
item.description: Where Am I from? I began this blog in the summer of 2018, mostly because I needed a place to put all of the things I do for fun. What better way than to build your own webssite and put all that crap there?? I have come across this beautiful post from the D3js website. It creates a plot of where the author has been.
